text:
From the very beginning, education
has been very important.
First, nurseries and then schools.
Now a university that you established.
Why is education so important for
SEKEM and what you're doing?

From the very beginning, the vision
my father had to establish

this intentional community was to enable
the potential unfolding of each

single member of this community
and all people attached.

So our focus - it was 45 years ago
and is today - is really human development.

We believe it's not about chamomile,
not about tea bags,
not about soils, or biodynamic agriculture.
All this is just serving
human development.
And hence,

for us, human development
is also not only limited

to kindergarten, school and university,
but it's a lifelong learning process.

The university of life, the
university of work

is for us as important as the university
for students or the school.
We are really trying -

we did from the very beginning
and we are doing this today.
We are continuously
allowing our

community members to invest time
in their potential unfolding,
up to 10% of their working time
in many different fields related to
music, arts, movement, painting,
but also gardening, or
studying religion, or whatever.

It doesn't have to be something
related to your job.
All this under
the idea that

there is a potential in every one of us
and many of us don't know what it is.
What is their inner call?
What is their ability?

What is the artist in them?
And so on.

This is what we are
trying to support
our students,
our community members to search for
and hopefully someday find
what it is - their inner call,

and obviously also how it is
linked to what the world needs from them -
the outer call.
So this is the major,

the focus, and center of the
of the whole SEKEM vision.
